heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: The Virtual Fracture Clinic (VFC) helps you recover from your injury without needing to come back to the hospital. This is called self-management. Use the rehabilitation plan in this leaflet to guide your recovery.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: Video about your injury and recovery
text: Watch this video to help your recovery. A doctor explains your injury and a physiotherapist shows how to do the exercises: www.fracturecare.co.uk/care-plans/foot/fracture-to-the-base-of-the-5th-metatarsal/

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: What is a 5th metatarsal base fracture?
text: This is a break in the long bone on the outside of the foot that connects to the little toe. This is called the 5th metatarsal.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: It takes about 6 to 12 weeks for this fracture to heal.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: Smoking slows down your healing. So, we advise that you stop smoking (including vaping) while your fracture heals. Talk to your GP or go to nhs.uk/better-health/quit-smoking/ for more information.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: You can expect to have foot pain and swelling for 3 to 6 months after your injury. Swelling is often worse at the end of the day.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: You can help reduce pain and swelling by: taking pain medication, raising your ankle above the level of your hip (elevate), using ice or cold packs.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: The boot protects your foot and will make you more comfortable. Wear the boot when you are standing and walking. You can take it off at night and at rest. You need to wear the boot for 3 weeks after your injury.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: Please tell us if you are diabetic; you may need a specialist boot.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: You are allowed to put weight through your foot. You may find it easier to use crutches in the early stages.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: It's important to start exercises as soon as possible. Good rehabilitation will improve your recovery. You can expect some discomfort to start with. Do not continue if the pain gets worse and you cannot tolerate it. Follow the instructions on the next pages.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: Follow-up appointments are not usually needed for this injury. Patients usually recover well with self-management.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: But please contact our team if: you still have significant pain and swelling after 3 months.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: Caring for your injury: weeks 1 to 6
text: Remember to wear your boot whenever standing and walking. You can remove the boot when resting, at night and to wash and dress. Wear a long sock in your boot.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: Caring for your injury: weeks 1 to 6
text: Using a cold pack will help with your pain and swelling. Use an ice pack or bag of frozen peas wrapped in a damp towel, put this on your foot for up to 15 minutes every few hours, and make sure the ice is not in direct contact with your skin.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: Caring for your injury: weeks 1 to 6
text: Try to rest your foot, especially in the first 24 to 72 hours. Raise your foot on a stool or cushions so it is above the level of your hip. This will help to reduce your swelling.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: It's important to move your ankle and foot as soon as you can. This promotes circulation and reduces the risk of developing a blood clot (deep vein thrombosis). Do these exercises 3 to 4 times a day. Start straight away. You do not need to push into pain.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: Point your foot up and down. Repeat 10 times.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: With your heels together, move your toes apart to turn the foot outwards. Repeat 10 times. Do this movement gently so you remain comfortable.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: Make gentle circles with your foot in one direction and then the other direction. Repeat 10 times.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: Caring for your injury: weeks 3 to 12
text: It is now 3 weeks since your injury. You need to stop wearing your boot all the time. This is so you can gradually get used to not needing it. Stop using it around your own home first. But keep wearing it for longer distances. Aim to be walking without your boot by 6 to 8 weeks after injury.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: Caring for your injury: weeks 3 to 12
text: You can expect mild discomfort and swelling. This may continue for up to 6 months.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: Keep doing your exercises until you have recovered full movement in your foot. Gradually increase your level of activity. You should avoid impact activity for 3 months. This includes running, jumping and dancing.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: It's hard for me to walk in my boot. What do I do? The boot has a thicker sole than normal shoes. This can make you feel uneven. Make sure you wear a supportive shoe or trainer on your uninjured foot. This will reduce stress on other joints. For more advice, contact the VFC.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: I am diabetic. Is it ok for me to wear a boot? If you are diabetic, please contact us to discuss your boot. This is particularly important if you have problems with your skin or sensation. We may provide you with a specialist diabetic boot.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: When can I drive again? You can return to driving when: you are no longer using your boot, you can walk comfortably and, you can perform an emergency stop pain free. Always test how well you can drive in a safe place first.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: How can I get a 'fit note' for work? Ask your GP for a 'fitness for work' statement. You can give this to your employer.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: What do I do with my crutches and boot when I no longer need them? Please return your crutches to the fracture clinic or to A&E. They can be refurbished and reused. Your boot cannot be used again, so you do not need to return it.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: We're here to help if you've got concerns about your injury, symptoms or exercises. Call us on 077 7455 5354 (Monday to Friday between 09.00 and 17.00). Or you can email imperial.vfc@nhs.net.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
text: So, please contact us if you: have any concerns about your injury or symptoms, cannot follow this rehabilitation plan, are expecting an appointment letter and have not received it, need help with your boot, brace or sling.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: How do I make a comment about my visit?
text: We aim to provide the best possible service. Staff will be happy to answer your questions. So, if you have suggestions or comments about your visit, please talk to a member of staff. Or you can contact the patient advice and liaison service (PALS). Call 020 3312 7777 (10.00 – 16.00, Monday to Friday) or email PALS at imperial.pals@nhs.net. The PALS team will listen to your concerns and is often able to help solve problems on your behalf.

heading: 5th metatarsal base fracture - Information for patients, relatives and carers
topic: How do I make a comment about my visit?
text: Or, to complain, contact our complaints department: Call 020 3312 1337 / 1349 or email: ICHC-tr.Complaints@nhs.net. Or write to: Complaints department, fourth floor, Salton House, St Mary's Hospital, Praed Street, London W2 1NY.
